headline: Why Verizon and AT&T Stocks Fizzled on Friday
summary: Concerns about a top rival's performance put big telecoms Verizon (NYSE: VZ) and AT&T (NYSE: T) in the investor doghouse on Friday.  The aforementioned peer is T-Mobile US (NASDAQ: TMUS), which published its first-quarter results after market close on Thursday.  In terms of operational metrics, postpaid net customer additions of 495,000 topped AT&T's latest figure and contrasted very favorably with Verizon's decline.

headline: Is Verizon Still a Defensive Dividend Stock After Soft Subscriber Growth?
summary: Postpaid subscribers have wireless plans that are billed monthly, as opposed to prepaid subscribers, who pay for their services upfront.  Prepaid subscribers generally are not as affluent, and the business has much more churn.  On the postpaid wireless front, the company disappointed.

raw.headline: Is Verizon Still a Defensive Dividend Stock After Soft Subscriber Growth?

headline: T-Mobile Is Sliding. Why Solid Earnings Weren’t Enough to Support the Stock.
summary: T-Mobile US T-Mobile US  posted better-than-expected results on Thursday, but investors appeared to zero in on slowing growth in the company’s main wireless division.  T-Mobile said first-quarter adjusted earnings were $2.58 a share on revenue of $20.9 billion.  Analysts surveyed by FactSet were expecting the wireless provider to report earnings of $2.47 a share on revenue of $20.6 billion.

Analysts surveyed by FactSet were expecting the wireless provider to report earnings of $2.47 a share on revenue of $20.6 billion.

headline: Want $2,600 in Annual Dividends? Invest $16,000 in Each of These 3 Stocks.
summary: Generating some extra dividend income is never a bad idea, especially now when costs are rising.  Here's a look at how investing $16,000 in each of these stocks can generate $2,600 in annual dividends for you, and why they are worth hanging on to for years.  A big motivation for investing in Verizon stock today is for its dividend, which yields 6.2%.
